allReviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Got a bad phone
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2023
allReviews.body: The Phone was in a factory package but upon opening it would not charge after many attempts it finally began to charge.  So I began setting up the phone . Initially I was on WiFi so setup proceeded as expected,  then I switched off WiFi and discovered that the phone was locked from att Sim use. I noticed that the phone was a tracphone so I contacted tfunlock and after 24 Hrs was able to unlock. But the phone would not work on data plan so I researched how to setup the APN settings to look like my other phone but they were greyed out.  There were four options before a factory reset and on the forth I was able to force APN settings that worked with att but it was still using the VMNO setting that are forced on tracfone which delivers way weaker signal than my other phones about 20 dbm's which is significant signal loss.  So  thought ID contact the manufacturer.  I connected the charger and attempted to continue setting up the next day but the phone has not recharged since and I have tried two different chargers and 3 different cords all of which work on my other phones.

    Good phone, screen too dim
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2024
allReviews.body: This is my third Galaxy A10e, the other two were bought new from Tracfone a few years ago and are still working fine. I needed an extra one for a trip, so I could use another SIM card for roaming. All is well with the phone, except that the screen is dimmer than my older original one. The screen on this renewed one looks dimmer and off-white in color, when the brightness it at the same level as my other phone. I normally have my brightness down low around 10% on the scroll bar, but have to turn brightness up to around 50% on the scroll bar in order to get it even close to the brightness on the original, but that will use more battery power to run it with the brightness up so high, and it's still not as bright as the old one. I sent a message to the seller about this issue.When I took the phone out of the box, before turning it on, I noticed that it looks brand new, the screen and the entire phone. Amazing in that respect. It had a 68% charge, so I charged it up to 100%, then set up the phone and it's already down to 68% again.

allReviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Poorly engineered, UN-reliable.
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2023
allReviews.body: I have owned 3 of these cell phones now.  Bought the first in October 2019.  Lasted about one year, then the screen went black.  It was not dropped or abused.  Most of the time it was tethered  to my computer for internet service, so I could run my Amazon seller business.  When the screen went black it was a disaster.  With Amazon's two-step verification, I could not access my Amazon account to buy a replacement cell phone, confirm my Marketplace sales, or ever turn off my store.  Tried Walmart for a replacement, but they had nothing that would work with my 4G T-Mobile account.  I had no choice but to drive over 100 miles to a uBreakiFix same day repair shop.  The screen was replaced for about $100.  More than a year later, same thing happened again.  Paid another $100.  6 months later, same thing, $100.  Next time the it happened within the 3 month  uBreakiFix warranty (now owned by Asurion), so they fixed it for free.  So I decided it would be cheaper to buy a back-up Samsung Galaxy A10e.  I purchased an unlocked one here and made sure I got the 2 year Asurion warranty.  That phone was DOA.  Returned it and received refunds for both the phone and the warranty.  Bought another.  Less the a month later the screen just went black again, but I was still connected to Amazon, so I quickly purchased a Google Pixel 3 64GB Unlocked GSM & CDMA 4G LTE, with an Asurion warranty.  Then I returned the third phone for both refunds.  I hope the Pixel 3 works better.

allReviews.title:
2.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Beware of refurb budget phones. Oem parts cost more than than the phone!
allReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2021
allReviews.body: The phone is probably a decent budget phone when it's new. I bought this as a replacement for a much better but also much older phone for a teenager.2 stars because, even for a budget phone, it felt super cheap. Now, I suspect this was most likely due to it being a renewed product. Most often I think refurb phones are OK. In this case though I think whoever fixed up this phone used cheap replacements and did a bad job of it because oem parts would cost almost as much as the phone!. From day one  the phone was nearly unusable due to constant phantom touches all over the screen that would hang up calls, switch between or close apps, and cause the screen to get stuck alternating between the two home screens, like someone frantically swiping left and right on the home screen. Anyway, as I mentioned the phone screen also felt super cheap and it even started to separate along the top edge. Within a couple days the screen also started to crack and what little glue was holding on the screen must have given up because the whole screen (glass, digitizer and lcd) just fell right off. I'm sure this was the exception to the rule but just be aware you stand a better chance of getting a lemon on a refurb/renewed phone.  Better to buy refurb flagship phones. You can get a decent new budget phone for slightly more than this renewed budget phone.Moto G anyone?

criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2023
criticalReviews.body: The Phone was in a factory package but upon opening it would not charge after many attempts it finally began to charge.  So I began setting up the phone . Initially I was on WiFi so setup proceeded as expected,  then I switched off WiFi and discovered that the phone was locked from att Sim use. I noticed that the phone was a tracphone so I contacted tfunlock and after 24 Hrs was able to unlock. But the phone would not work on data plan so I researched how to setup the APN settings to look like my other phone but they were greyed out.  There were four options before a factory reset and on the forth I was able to force APN settings that worked with att but it was still using the VMNO setting that are forced on tracfone which delivers way weaker signal than my other phones about 20 dbm's which is significant signal loss.  So  thought ID contact the manufacturer.  I connected the charger and attempted to continue setting up the next day but the phone has not recharged since and I have tried two different chargers and 3 different cords all of which work on my other phones.

criticalReviews.title:
1.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Poorly engineered, UN-reliable.
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2023
criticalReviews.body: I have owned 3 of these cell phones now.  Bought the first in October 2019.  Lasted about one year, then the screen went black.  It was not dropped or abused.  Most of the time it was tethered  to my computer for internet service, so I could run my Amazon seller business.  When the screen went black it was a disaster.  With Amazon's two-step verification, I could not access my Amazon account to buy a replacement cell phone, confirm my Marketplace sales, or ever turn off my store.  Tried Walmart for a replacement, but they had nothing that would work with my 4G T-Mobile account.  I had no choice but to drive over 100 miles to a uBreakiFix same day repair shop.  The screen was replaced for about $100.  More than a year later, same thing happened again.  Paid another $100.  6 months later, same thing, $100.  Next time the it happened within the 3 month  uBreakiFix warranty (now owned by Asurion), so they fixed it for free.  So I decided it would be cheaper to buy a back-up Samsung Galaxy A10e.  I purchased an unlocked one here and made sure I got the 2 year Asurion warranty.  That phone was DOA.  Returned it and received refunds for both the phone and the warranty.  Bought another.  Less the a month later the screen just went black again, but I was still connected to Amazon, so I quickly purchased a Google Pixel 3 64GB Unlocked GSM & CDMA 4G LTE, with an Asurion warranty.  Then I returned the third phone for both refunds.  I hope the Pixel 3 works better.

criticalReviews.title:
2.0 out of 5 stars







  
  
    Beware of refurb budget phones. Oem parts cost more than than the phone!
criticalReviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2021
criticalReviews.body: The phone is probably a decent budget phone when it's new. I bought this as a replacement for a much better but also much older phone for a teenager.2 stars because, even for a budget phone, it felt super cheap. Now, I suspect this was most likely due to it being a renewed product. Most often I think refurb phones are OK. In this case though I think whoever fixed up this phone used cheap replacements and did a bad job of it because oem parts would cost almost as much as the phone!. From day one  the phone was nearly unusable due to constant phantom touches all over the screen that would hang up calls, switch between or close apps, and cause the screen to get stuck alternating between the two home screens, like someone frantically swiping left and right on the home screen. Anyway, as I mentioned the phone screen also felt super cheap and it even started to separate along the top edge. Within a couple days the screen also started to crack and what little glue was holding on the screen must have given up because the whole screen (glass, digitizer and lcd) just fell right off. I'm sure this was the exception to the rule but just be aware you stand a better chance of getting a lemon on a refurb/renewed phone.  Better to buy refurb flagship phones. You can get a decent new budget phone for slightly more than this renewed budget phone.Moto G anyone?

criticalReviews.body: The listing indicated that this was an unlocked phone,  with no other identifying information,  leading me to believe that this phone could be used with any carrier.  I did not do further research,  which I should have done. I would have learned that tracofones phones are notorious for not being compatible with other carriers. Just putting my SIM card into this phone suspended my account with my carrier. For those who don't know,  you need to check a phone's IMEI number with your carrier to confirm compatibility.  This listing did not include that information, which makes the purchase risky.  The only reason I'm doing 2 stars is because I should have done more research before buying and the fact that so far the return process has been easy enough.
